This is correct, fees are going to be zero, until they aren't: once demand is above a threshold, they'll shoot up. And they will be sticky: once up, they will remain high even when demand has dropped below phase shift.

Analyzed here: http://www.hec.ca/finance/Fichier/Ohara2017.pdf … 

/CC @soumyab8 https://twitter.com/ncweaver/status/1000390034699173888 …

1115075380472422401.text: As long as fees are set and charged using a first price auction mechanism, users will be forced to guess the optimal amount to pay. A second price auction mechanism, like http://hackingdistributed.com/2019/01/22/doing-fees-right/ …, fixes these problems in the presence of full blocks.https://twitter.com/el33th4xor/status/1115059581690970112 …

1101556542174908417.text:
Good thread why fee spikes are a problem in cryptocurrencies and how we can help mitigate them by cleverly adapting the rich second price auction literature to the cryptocurrency environment.

1061681104460177408.text:
In PoS coins, you can't increase the cost of production which is fairly low. This also means that the lower bound on the price is much lower than in PoW. Thus, the price for PoS coins will be determined entirely by the demand for the coin.

Am I missing anything? (3/3)

1061681103294156800.text: If a coin costs $100 to produce, then it's price will be *at least* $100 since no producer will sell a coin for < $100. And if the price is greater than $100, then there's an arbitrage opportunity. Since the rate of production can't increase, the cost will increase. (2/3)

1048086298563698688.text: We saw that BTC's orphan rate was less than 1%. ETH pushes more transactions per second but has a higher uncle rate (between 6-10%). Spy mining reduces the throughput of the network without compromising security- to prevent the perf hit, faster block propagation is required.pic.twitter.com/vs4ZwvBKIz

1048086297166929920.text: This is not all that surprising- the orphan rates in ETH are much higher than BTC, as we reported on here: https://arxiv.org/abs/1801.03998 . Spy mining is a natural way to combat that. Another way to achieve the same goal is with a relay network like we're building @bloXrouteLabs.https://twitter.com/el33th4xor/status/1047638627193442304 …

Also, this is orthogonal to the other benefits of diversity in an org/field. (2/2)

1024678592020733952.text: There is no fundamental reason why some other resource cannot be used to weigh the votes. If that other thing is greener, that can only be a good thing. Additionally, this does not give up any security whatsoever since you're doing the same thing as PoW just more efficiently. 3/3

1024678590942724098.text: The problem with plain old voting is that an adversary can spam identities. Permissioned consensus gets around this by making the identities well known. PoW gets around this by weighing each identity according to how much CPU it uses. 2/3

1024678589541822464.text: Recently, I realized what the confusion around PoW is about: people believe that PoW is securing the chain through its energy usage. From that lens, any solution that uses less energy is inherently less secure. But this is wrong: all consensus algorithms work through voting. 1/3https://twitter.com/el33th4xor/status/1024593927972839424 …

1005118820359589889.text: So, I have one request: can we focus on solving the energy consumption problem instead of acting like its a necessary feature?

1005118567891853313.text: Even if this was true, it demonstrates a huge weakness of PoW: The banking system can launch a 51% attack by increasing its costs by 0.04%.

1005118566159601666.text: This is a poor comparison. Bitcoin's adoption isn't close to the level of the other comparison points. Additionally, none of the economic costs (e.g. hardware, maintaining a mining farm, etc) were taken into account for Bitcoin, when they were for the other categories.https://twitter.com/ArminVanBitcoin/status/1005085081046736896 …

997217363987755009.text: That being said, there are tons of other proposals being attempted and deployed. I look forward to the day when the energy consumption of cryptocurrencies is no longer a valid criticism.

997217362993664001.text: Bitcoin's consensus layer is *not* very decentralized. If the top 20 miners in Bitcoin got together and ran BFT, that would be *more* decentralized than the current Bitcoin consensus layer. We're using so much energy to get something that's not that decentralized!

997217361924108288.text: The right response to Bitcoin's energy consumption is to ask how we can do better (whether that's Proof of Stake, proof of useful work, the recently released Avalanche paper, or something else), not to blindly defend it.

995486798301290506.text: I strongly believe in privacy preserving systems, but their track record compared to non-privacy preserving alternatives is poor. This time may be different and differentiating on privacy may be enough, but why risk it?

995486795910602757.text: This is not entirely good news for cryptocurrencies. Cryptocurrencies provide stronger privacy guarantees and ease of use (for some use cases). Digitized fiat has the potential to compete on ease of use. If cryptocurrencies are easier to use though, then it's a game changer...https://twitter.com/el33th4xor/status/994993519851900929 …

993928217466720263.text: Interesting thread. When talking to some econ/finance people, I also get the response that most token's prices are just speculation. I can't wait for the day where I can respond with the value that tokens *have* created, not just the *potential* that they have.https://twitter.com/VinnyLingham/status/993888718015614976 …

993263720502611971.text: 4/4 As far as I know, there is more than 1 dominant ASIC manufacturer, so mining is probably *more* decentralized than the codebases are... So shouldn't coins try to get many independent implementations *first* before changing the PoW algorithm?

993263719365914630.text: 3/4 The only way to remove that trust is to have multiple codebases, but most coins do not. https://arewedecentralizedyet.com/  shows that only ETH, BCH and LTC has more than 1 implementation account for > 90% of the nodes

993263718342545408.text: 2/4 To most users, the node codebase is a black box that they just run (kinda like how ASICs are for everyone...). They won't be able to fix it if there's a subtle bug somewhere. So, there is a significant amount of trust in the developers.

993263716387958784.text: 1/4 Question: why is ASIC-resistance talked about so much while the importance of having multiple implementations essentially ignored? Both things require users to put trust in a small group (ASIC manufacturers versus devs).

985619246670602240.text: 4/4 Knowing the outcome of events changes the probability space in weird ways (according to Bayes rule). For another (unrelated) example of weird Bayes rules implications, look up the Monty Hall problem.

985619245596803073.text: 3/4 Because in every run of 6 rolls, I'm expected to see a "1". This is true of any random run. However, if I've seen a roll already, that roll already has a probability of 0 or 1. This expected run trick only works for rolls I *haven't* seen yet.

985619244418203655.text: 2/4 Suppose I told you I had rolled 100 times already and haven't won yet. What does that tell you about how many times I still have to roll? Absolutely nothing, since the rolls are independent! Now, why does this get hard?

985619242866311168.text: 1/4 I've been seeing a lot of discussion around this. Here's another way to look at memoryless processes. Suppose we're talking about a dice rolling game and you "win" whenever you roll a 1.(This is just like Bitcoin mining, btw!)https://twitter.com/PeterRizun/status/985345071036813313 …

977261316246245383.text: Additionally, Falcon/FIBRE serve only Bitcoin (and for Falcon- Bitcoin Cash). There are many other great coins out there too. By making bloXroute general purpose, any improvements made to bloXroute will be available to all cryptocurrencies instead of just Bitcoin/Bitcoin Cash.

977261315164078080.text: That would put Falcon/FIBRE in a trusted position. So, by making bloXroute trustless, all of the innovations that Falcon and FIBRE made can be directly translated into throughput gains. By incorporating it, the network can survive even when individuals move on.

977261313532616704.text: Love the skepticism, but you're missing one concept. bloXroute is an *untrusted* relay network. That word is key. Currently, FIBRE/Falcon offer great benefits to Bitcoin BUT Bitcoin cannot increase block size and rely on Falcon and FIBRE for block relay.https://twitter.com/TheBlueMatt/status/977246371895042049 …

976813724894973952.text: Happy to announce bloXroute today! It takes a hard look at the network layer and attacks the scalability problem from a direction that's been largely ignored. 976545553508175874.text: So it's very hard to get a comparison of illegal activity between traditional centralized systems and blockchains.

976545551691997184.text: There was a pretty nice paper on quantifying the illegal transactions in Bitcoin here: https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3102645 …. When the author was asked if this was possible to do with traditional currencies, he said his techniques directly apply if he has access to all transaction activity.

976545549792043010.text: Interesting thread. One additional point: with blockchains, it becomes possible to attempt to quantify these things. With traditional centralized systems, there may not be anyone that knows the answer.https://twitter.com/el33th4xor/status/976538440102744065 …

974735336902414336.text: Some countries use *mobile phone credits* as cash since they trust their phone providers more than their banks. Even a blockchain that does something as simple as bookkeeping can have *immense* value to the right audience.

974735335790907392.text: In the US, many of these large institutions are fairly trustworthy. In third world countries, "bad bookkeeping" is actually a trust problem. Even if a bank tells you what your balance is, it's hard to know if they're telling the truth.

974735333785939968.text: I asked someone in finance about what problems blockchain can solve in finance. Many of the answers were basically solving poor bookkeeping problems. My initial thought was: "Isn't the answer here: use a replicated database?" It turned out not to be so.https://twitter.com/secparam/status/974704270640668677 …

973976404525232130.text: Instead of computer security, what if we looked at this as a financial analyst? They're using their expertise to make financial decisions and write articles about which stocks are going to do well/poorly. Isn't that all the security person is doing?https://twitter.com/mjg59/status/973942237141676033 …

973204358757257217.text: Finally, it's super exciting to be part of a field that's generating this much excitement and buzz. There's so much cool work going on and it's great seeing people getting interested in it.

973204357515808776.text: If you buy into a coin worth $500M, you should be asking if there's a way for the coin to go to at least 10-30x that (i.e. $5-15B in value). Otherwise, you're just gambling. Which is fine! As long as you know that's what you're doing.

973204356056125441.text: While cryptocurrencies are exciting, these are *unproven* technologies. If things go well, you should be expecting to make many multiples on your initial investment. And *never* invest more than you can afford to lose.

973204354365870082.text: I think he does a *great* job showing both why this is an exciting space and why you should be #craefulgang.
